Algernon’s brotherCOMMA Ernest Mervyn EvansCOMMA died on June 28 after being injured in a subway accident.

Joseph Morris wrote the letter from DundaleCOMMA the Morris family estate in Villanova. Now part of the university’s campusCOMMA the mansion was erected in 1890 as a retreat from the city for Israel Morris’s son Theodore (who had just attained the presidency of Morris & WheelerCOMMA his father’s iron company) and his many children. The building currently houses the development offices of Villanova University.

All information from Stokes’ Stokes Cope Emlen Evans Genealogy (1982)COMMA the printed eulogy of Ernest Mervyn EvansCOMMA and various Villanova University websites. A picture of Dundale may be found online at www.villanova.edu/maps/bldgs/dundale.htm.

Letter is from the steamer Dalmatia. Stationery bears crest in blue with the word“Vorwaerts” (forwardCOMMA in German) under an anchor and crown. Underneath crest are the words “Oesterreichischer Lloyd. Triest.” Large watermark depicting a crown and the words “Imperial Century.”

The city of Acre was captured by King Philip Augustus of France and King Richard the Lion-Hearted of England during the Third Crusade (1189-1192).

BakshishCOMMA stemming from the Persian for “to giveCOMMA” means to tip.

The stories of TabithaCOMMA Simon the TannerCOMMA and Peter’s vision are from Acts 9:26-10:15. Peter raised Tabitha (also called Dorcas)COMMA a charitable womanCOMMA from the dead in the town of Joppa. He stayed there at the home of Simon the Tanner (today the house is open for visitors)COMMA where he had his vision of animals trapped in a sheetCOMMA which the Lord bade him to eat. When he refusedCOMMA protesting that the Lord had designated some of them unclean for consumptionCOMMA the Lord repliedCOMMA “What God hath cleansedCOMMA make not thou common.” Following this visionCOMMA Peter visited a Gentile named Cornelius and widened the scope of Christian ministry (then practiced within JudaismCOMMA as it was considered unclean for a Jew to minister to a Gentile) to include those outside the Jewish faith.

Co. Laois lies in the ancient province of Leinster in IrelandCOMMA and is also known as Co. Leix or Queen’s Co. The Dictionary of Quaker Biography lists Lacka House as the residenceCOMMA four miles outside the town of MountrathCOMMA of the birthplace of William Pim and the home of his grandfatherCOMMA John Pim. Mountrath was founded by Sir Charles Coote in the seventeenth centuryCOMMA who established a manufacturing and industrial center on his estate. The town supported over the years an ironworksCOMMA an oil millCOMMA two distilleriesCOMMA a breweryCOMMA a linen manufacturing businessCOMMA and a cotton spinning business.

The town of CalnCOMMA PACOMMA lies in Chester County and is named for CalneCOMMA WiltshireCOMMA EnglandCOMMA where many of the town’s original inhabitants emigrated from. The meeting house in Caln dates from 1726. A century after his emigrationCOMMA William Pim’s descendants remained in good standing in Caln. In Eugene L. DiOrio’s Chester County: A Traveler’s Album (MarcelineCOMMA MO: Walsworth PublishingCOMMA 1980)COMMA Richard Pim is listed as a prominent landowner in 1837 who built a still-standing six-sided schoolhouse for his children.

“Both girls” who join Sibylla in greeting the Cope sisters are Sibylla’s two daughters Annie Sayne and Mary Morris. Her two sons working on the railroads are Frederick Cox Morris and Caleb Carmalt Morris.

Title: 1841 AprilCOMMA to FrankCOMMA Philada.
Creator: TaberCOMMA CharlesCOMMA 1822-1887
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; LambCOMMA CharlesCOMMA 1775-1834; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897
Subject: American poetry--Quaker authors; Classical literature; Quotations in literature; Quakers--Humor; Letter writing; Newport (R.I.)--Description and Travel
Notes:
Throughout the letter the author quotes liberally from other writers and sources. A partial list of identifications follows.
“greatness sympathises with greatness”: essayist William HazlittCOMMA “The Indian Judges”
“you can’t get a barrel of praties into a bushel basket”: aphorismCOMMA origin unknown
“some are born to greatnessCOMMA some achieve greatnessCOMMA and some have greatness thrust upon them”: William ShakespeareCOMMA Twelfth Night
“Tantaene animis coelestibus irae?” [In heavenly minds can such resentments dwell?]: VirgilCOMMA The Aeneid
“Memory is mortal forgiveness divine” [this is perhaps a restatement of “To err is humanCOMMA to forgive divine”]: Alexander PopeCOMMA “Essay on Criticism”
The Biblical admonition to “turn the other cheek” may be found in Matthew 5:38-40.
“cold obstruction” [in reference to death]: William ShakespeareCOMMA Measure for Measure
“Wellerism” [“a form of comparison in which a familiar saying or proverb is identified with what was said by someone in a specified but humorously inapposite situation” : from characters in Charles DickensCOMMA Pickwick Papers (definition from Oxford English Dictionary)
“No man is a hero to his valet-de-chambre”: Marshal Catinat or Madame de Corneul

The watermark is as follows:
J Whitman
Turkey Mill
1839

On the last page of the letterCOMMA the following text is written in pencilCOMMA in another handCOMMA probably that of E.S.C.: 2 letters of Chas. Tabor to Francis R. Cope - 1841 (F.R.C. aged 20 - C.T. about same age - ) C.T. had published in “L’Entreprise”COMMA a seranade written by F.R.C. When advised of the theft F.R.C. sends another poem entitled the “Thief.”

For a description of many of the geographic locations mentioned in the letterCOMMA see Newport and How to See It (Newport: Davis & PitmanCOMMA 1869).

A “fippenny bit” is a corruption of “five-penny bitCOMMA” a Spanish coin worth half a real or 6.25 cents. It was called fourpence in New EnglandCOMMA fip in PennsylvaniaCOMMA sixpence in New YorkCOMMA and a picayune in Louisiana. (Webster’s Dictionary)

Notes:
Author mentions Stewart’sCOMMA one of the first department storesCOMMA located at 280 BroadwayCOMMA New York (N.Y.). Known as the "Marble Palace" for its stone pillarsCOMMA this new concept helped make shopping fashionable for wealthy women.

Fernando Wood served nine intermittent terms in CongressCOMMA beginning in 1841COMMA and three terms as Mayor of New York City. The riots that Martha writes about in this letter stem from rival gubernatorial and mayoral appointments to replace the New York City Street Commissioner. (For an in-depth look at this crisisCOMMA see Jerome MushkatCOMMA Ch. 5COMMA “The Political MayorCOMMA” in Fernando Wood: A Political Biography (KentCOMMA OH: Kent State University PressCOMMA 1990)).

Solon Robinson's "Hot Corn” vignettes of city life among the impoverished and immigrant communities were later collected in a bookCOMMA entitled “Hot Corn StoriesCOMMA” which must have been known to Martha and to Anne either in serial or book form.

The “little Katy” mentioned in the letter may not refer to a family member but rather to the title character of one of Robinson’s stories. HoweverCOMMA hsc0022 mentions a girl named Katy staying with the Leeds family.

Dictionary defines collodion as “a solution of gun-cotton in etherCOMMA forming a colourles gummy liquidCOMMA which dries rapidly in the airCOMMA owing to evaporation of the ether.” Collodion was used in photography to cover glass plates as well as in medicine to cover wounds.

Tarleton muslin is a stiffCOMMA lightweightCOMMA finely woven cotton fabric.

A map of Newport and several of the buildings mentioned in the letterCOMMA including the building standing on the corner of Bellevue and BerkleyCOMMA from which Emily wrote this letterCOMMA may be found on p. 217 of John Sterngrass’ First Resorts.

John of Bologna’s masterpiece is held to be his bronze engraving of Mercury.

“Angelo’s Night and DayCOMMA” to which Joseph Simpson refers in the letterCOMMA are likely Michelangelo’s sculptures of Twilight and Dawn (completed in 1534) in the Medici Chapel in the Church of San Lorenzo in Florence.

The workpeople that Joseph Simpson mentions in his letter are likely the people working at his spinning mill at Mayfield. Joseph and his brother revived the ailing mill and built housing and reading rooms for their workersCOMMA gradually improving relations between the workers and themselves and increasing the mill’s profitability. From the Dictionary of Quaker Biography.

Notes:
This record contains two associated lettersCOMMA one enclosed within the other.

The watermark reads A Cowan & SonsCOMMA 1851COMMA Patent.

Connaught is one of the four ancient provinces of IrelandCOMMA with UlsterCOMMA LeinsterCOMMA and Munster comprising the other three. Connaught contains the present-day counties of MayoCOMMA SligoCOMMA RoscommonCOMMA GalwayCOMMA and Leitrim. ConnaughtCOMMA located on the midwestern coast of the islandCOMMA relied heavily on agriculture for its businessCOMMA and the Famine of the mid-nineteenth century especially affected this area.

Newcastle is located in County DownCOMMA which is part of present-day Northern Ireland. Newcastle remains a seaside resort town known for its scenery. The town lies at the foot of Slieve DonardCOMMA Northern Ireland⼯a>??s highest pointCOMMA and its beaches and golf courses attract thousands of summer vistors.

The Belfast Ladies Relief Association for Connaught was an interdenominational group dedicated to providing for those left hungry and destitute by the potato famine in 1845. The Association was begun on January 1COMMA 1847COMMA by Rev. John EdgarCOMMA whose prior public work dealt with temperance issues. Its primary focus was raising moneyCOMMA although many of its members did involve themselves more personally in relief work. Their primary methods of funding involved door-to-door canvassing and the operation of a Bazaar of Ladies⼯a>?? Work in Belfast. Circulars with statistics and stories of the devastation were published to aid the ladies in their appeal.

Although food and clothing were at first the items most soughtCOMMA the women had loftier goals: "to ⼯a>??improveCOMMA by industryCOMMA the temporal condition of the poor females of Connaught and their spiritual [condition] by the truth of the bible.⼯a>??" (from Luddy 22) Schools teaching needlework and knitting were established throughout Connaught. Information from Maria LuddyCOMMA "Women and Philanthropy in Nineteenth-Century IrelandCOMMA " in WomenCOMMA PhilanthropyCOMMA and Civil SocietyCOMMA edited by Kathleen D. McCarthy (Bloomington: Indiana University PressCOMMA 2001) and the First Report of the Belfast Ladies' AssociationCOMMA BelfastCOMMA 6 March 1847.

Title: 1898 November 8COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to dear Cousin Clementine
Creator: EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Subject: Poetry
Notes: Acrostic poem.
Transcript:
For dear Cousin Clementine

Clustering round theeCOMMA cousin mineCOMMA
Linger memories sweet -
EachCOMMA as tiny floweret hidCOMMA
Musing in quiet retreat;
E'en undiscovered and unseen
Neath tramp of busy feetCOMMA
Till suddenly it springs to light
In beauty most complete -
NewCOMMA in a glory all its ownCOMMA
Enfolding perfume sweet. CloseCOMMA close around these hearts of ours O'er briars & ill weeds creepingCOMMA Peep forth the blue Forget-me-notsCOMMA Each freshCOMMA as waked from sleeping. Woodbourne Nov 8th/98
